name: p-aminophenylethanol
Reason: The basic unit for p-aminophenyl ethanol is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The amino (NH2) substituent generally increases the melting point due to the potential for intermolecular hydrogen bonding; this might add around +80°C to the melting point. The hydroxyethyl (-CH2CH2OH) group also involves hydrogen bonding, likely contributing an additional +60°C. The combination of the NH2 and -CH2CH2OH groups on the benzene ring, which are para to each other, allows for an intramolecular hydrogen bond, potentially reducing the increase that would be expected if they were separate (+10°C reduction considered).

name: p-aminophenylethanol
Reason: The basic unit for p-aminophenyl ethanol is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The amino (NH2) group introduces the potential for intermolecular hydrogen bonding, which has a significant effect on melting point due to increased intermolecular forces; this might add around +50°C as a conservative estimate since outright adding 80°C seems significantly high for a single amino group. The hydroxyethyl (-CH2CH2OH) group also supports hydrogen bonding, potentially contributing an additional +30°C. However, since the amino and hydroxyethyl groups are para to each other, they limit the overall increase by enabling intramolecular hydrogen bonding, which would reduce the added melting point elevation due to lessening intermolecular interactions; this might account for a reduction of about -20°C.

name: p-aminophenylethanol
Reason: The basic unit phenol has a melting point of 41 degrees Celsius. The amino group (-NH2) is expected to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which typically increases the melting point significantly; for small molecules, this can be estimated as a +50 increase. The ethylene glycol side chain (-CH2CH2OH) also forms hydrogen bonds, which can further raise the melting point. However, this group is flexible and less effective in creating a rigid, lattice structure necessary for a high melting point, so its effect will be less than that of the amino group. This can be estimated as a +20 increase. These additive effects result in the prediction for the melting point of p-aminophenylethanol.
